docs.lead_paragraph: In the gloom before dawn, under the hulking metal girders in Queens Plaza, the Department of Correction bus cruised to a stop. The doors opened, and 30 Rikers Island inmates poured into the trash-strewn street to freedom. The first man kicked the bus as waiting buddies whooped. Others slapped high-fives and called to the few prostitutes still slouching by at 5:30 A.M. Most, lugging their belongings in oversize bags of clear plastic or brown paper, loped quickly toward the glow of two all-night doughnut shops.

headline.main: Back on the Streets Without a Safety Net; Critics Assail Lack of Followup Care For Freed Inmates With Mental Ills

docs.abstract: Class-action lawsuit accuses New York City of releasing mentally ill inmates without follow-up care; Justice Louise Gruner Gans has issued temporary restraining on behalf of two plaintiffs in suit, requiring city to provide them with medication and referrals for expedited Medicaid, treatment and shelter; advocates say that city treats more than 15,000 seriously mentally ill inmates as patients each year, but typically releases them the same way it does any other inmate, forcing them into a revolving door of deterioration and re-arrest; photo (M)
